message.content:
cs.DS, cs.CC, cs.CG, cs.GT, cs.SI. 

The paper deals with the computational complexity of fair redistricting, which involves partitioning a geographic region into districts that satisfy certain criteria. This problem can be modeled as a graph partitioning problem, which falls under the category of algorithms and data structures (cs.DS). The proof of NP-hardness involves reducing planar k-means, a clustering problem, to fair redistricting, which suggests that computational complexity (cs.CC) and computational geometry (cs.CG) may also be relevant sub-categories. Additionally, the problem of fair redistricting has implications for game theory (cs.GT) and social and information networks (cs.SI), as it involves balancing competing interests and ensuring adequate representation.
